segments.text: When you were growing up in Bryant, what did you do for fun?
At what age?
Well, you moved here when you were 12, so say 12 to 20.
Well, when I came here when I was 12,
Of course, we had very little time.
I mean, that was true of the entire society.
We walked to and from school, and we were close enough to the school and were given enough time to go to our homes for lunch.
So that meant that we made
four trips a day to and from school.
And then I had chores to do around the house at all times.
Every day I had to carry my part of the load, such as bringing in the wood to fill the wood boxes at the fireplace.
Shoveling out the hashes, carrying out the hashes.
Just tasks that a boy of that age could accomplish.
And then generally on good days when we could, well in the fall we'd play a little sand lock football.
Five or six or ten neighborhood boys would get out and play.
At another time it would be baseball or something like that.
There was no organized play as such.
As a consequence, we became much more self-reliant than the youth of today and much less naive.
And I think had a whole lot better time.
Where did you live when you first came here?
I lived at 509, I believe it is, East 26th Street.
It's just one block from the courthouse.
It's only four blocks from Main Street.
But I was not permitted to go to Main Street.
Why was that?
It just wasn't done.
I didn't have any business being downtown on Main Street, so I was not permitted to go.
No other boy was here.
None of my associates were permitted to do it either.
Or if they were, I didn't know about it.
But of course, we did have the run of the town as such.
And due to the fact that there was a minimum of traffic, we could go.
virtually anyone's house that we knew.
If we told where we were going and then were we were all of us I guess it was social custom today instructed that we were not to stay for meals and to return to our own homes for our meals.
Summertime we
had household or yard tasks assigned to us virtually every day.
Working in gardens, mowing grass, pulling up weeds, doing those things.
Then after we got older, like in high school where we had more privileges, then we could come downtown.
Were the Moody Houses built then?
Yes.

We were allowed, as a growing up boy, if I did all my tasks, as I was supposed to throughout the week, I was granted an allowance, it was called, which was enough to attend the movie on Saturday and to get an ice cream soda, which was quite a treat.
and much looked forward to all week.
Were there any major social events for, say, the high school children?
Well, yes.
We had junior-senior dance and things like that, and we attended football games both here and to a lesser degree

important game there might be a caravan developed say to go to Caldwell a nearby town or if we had done rather well an excursion might be gotten up like one time I recall we went to Waco on we had a special train and the entire community participated
I would say that, of course, you always talk about the good old days weren't really that good, but really I think in some instances they were in that events were not so frequent.
People's time was more fully utilized in the necessities of living.
I mean, just the daily necessities of living.
When there were events, special events, well, I think you appreciated them somewhat more and you got a much broader participation.
There were numerous cultural events.
in the community also.
Yes, as was always true, but they were not quite as available as they are now.
I mean, but it wasn't too long till you could go buy cars, but for instance, they had a program out there in Guyana Hall when I was just a boy here, very much like the
town hall is now of national entertainment brought here.
For instance, I heard Paul Whiteman and his great jazz orchestra there when I was about 13 years old, which I've never forgotten.
It was quite an event because of the foot-patting nature of the music.
It was quite appealing to me and all these popular
so-called jazz music has always appealed to me ever since, but I shall never forget that.
What was the Depression like in Brown?
Did it have a great effect here?
No.
Brown was very fortunate.
We had very few vacant buildings.
In fact, virtually none.
None of our banks went under.
None of our
saving his institutions went under.
The professors and related employees at the university lived like absolute monarchs in teams.
They were on fixed salaries that had been set by the legislature some two years previous and those salaries

were not changed and legislature didn't meet in a special session to reduce them or anything and as a consequence a just ordinary professor out there could afford domestic help and many of them had they built rent houses and really did very well on dollar figures that would
be laughable to you today, but a man with $250 a month income at that time could just really have just almost anything that you might think you might want and save money too.
This was the consequence.
There was very little unemployment, relatively speaking.
The agricultural community suffered greatly because of virtually just total collapse of farm prices.
But there was active employment here in Bryan.
People did not lose their jobs and most of the businesses could and there was a supply of money.
Money was very dear to come by but we had quite a concentration of it.
Thanks to Texas A&M University and I would say that the hardest hit was the building trades but
There was, uh, Bryan and College Station were very fortunate, very fortunate indeed.
Were you here during the war, World War II?
Yes, a portion of it.
I served two and a half years in the military myself.
Did the war affect Bryan at all?
Well, yes, I think Bryan and College Station was affected by the war in many ways.
One, we had an air base located here called Bryan Field.
We also had numerous training units that were involved at Texas A&M.
It was a Navy unit, Air Force unit, Army units that were receiving various types of training in connection with the university.
There was various programs there then.
We, like many places, were certainly a
militarily oriented community at that time.
We did not have some of the disasters that other communities had in losing a lot of our young men by death, like Caldwell did, for instance.
They had part of their National Guard unit was at Corregidor.
little town like Caldwell, maybe 2,000 people in, lost 25 of their finest boys one afternoon.
People suffered a lot.
There was hardly ever a day that some friend or the son of
of a close family or something like that was not mortally wounded or lost or something.
War is not a very good time.
Was it as big a shock as they seem to make it in history books to everyone here?
What?
Was December 7th the shock that everyone says it is?
Do you remember that?
It was to me.
I was a young married person.
I had a young wife and three children, three little babies.
And I remember when it came on the radio that Sunday, it was very shocking, extremely shocking, but not frightening.
You weren't frightened?
No.
Were you mad?
Yes.
The whole, the whole nation was angry.
I think that, I'll say this, that I'm totally convinced, I was then, I continue to be to this day, that the National Administration totally failed to appraise
reaction and the attitude of the citizenship of the country.
Well, there was a deliberate effort.
Pearl Harbor was played down badly.
We were not advised until after World War II was over as to what actually happened at Pearl Harbor, how devastating it was.
But it is my best judgment.

From what I knew then and what I learned later and from my associates and everyone I knew, they thought the American people would, I mean the federal government thought the people of this country would collapse with fear.
The people would have fought them with their bare hands on the beaches, welcomed the opportunity.
There may be some places where people were fearful, but I never did hear of them and I never did meet anybody later that indicated there was any fear.
Where did you serve?
Just all over the United States.

I was 33 years old and I had a wife and three children and wasn't actually taken in until I tried for a commission in every branch of the service except the Marines and failed for physical reasons to qualify.
I finally ended up as an instructor in the Air Force Ground School.
Even though I could fly an airplane, I couldn't qualify as a flight instructor.
As a consequence, I was just moved from pillar to post all over the country.
So, most undistinguished military career.
Since World War II, Brian,
It's really started to grow.
It seemed like to me, I don't know exactly when it started, but it grew.
What areas do you think have grown the most in the Brian Codd Station?
You mean physically?
Physically, yeah.
Business and things like that.
Well, until recently,
The economic and the population growth of Bryan and College Station had been relatively uniform.
Going back as far as about 1935, I have seen studies
that indicated the growth to be at about 3.5% per annum, taken on an average of five-year bites, averaging out bites of five years each.
That was true until about 1960, maybe 1965.
The impression of substantial growth has been more acute
In the latter stages of that, I mean, 3% of 100 is only three.
You don't notice them.
But 3% of 1,000 becomes 30.
And you begin to notice them.
But when you get 3% of 10,000, you get 300.

and you can and you spot them rather so this is what's been occurring but somewhere about 65 or there on then the growth has begun to accelerate of course very obviously the primary area of growth has been in and around texas a&m university both in
residential housing, and now more recently, just an outbreak of student housing in the form of apartments.
The enrollment of Texas A&M University has increased more than a hundred percent in just relatively recent years.
When President Rutter took office, I think the student enrollment was only about ten thousand.
I understand now that it's near to 24,000, which has occurred, what, within eight years?
And of course, this has brought a tremendous influx of all sorts of services and supply outlets and things to service the population.
both student and I.
In fact, it's only, I would say it's only been in the last 15 years that the student population has been a factor in the community, and don't misunderstand that.
I mean, they were not disregarded, they were important, but they primarily lived on campus, supplied virtually all their needs on campus.
They,
They were not at all the factor in the community they have become.
Where do you think the outlook in this area is?
Is it good?
All I can do is take the figures of the Department of Commerce, which were confirmed by the Texas

Bureau of Business Research at Operation Connection University of Texas, which I believe rated Bryan and College Station as number one growth area in the next ten years in individual income in the whole United States, and number two in population.
I think that this is pretty well a factor.
I don't agree with the population thing is continuing.
I anticipate a plateauing in population, perhaps.
But obviously the personal income thing, which is really the most important in establishing a lifestyle and standard of living and so forth,
Do you think there's going to be any industrial growth?
Yes, but not in the sense that the average individual thinks in terms of.
I think that the industry that may come will be educationally related.
I think what we may see here is

more and more I don't know quite how to put it into words technologically oriented consulting firms or small what they call clean air type industries things like that probably service related industries more than
more than the manufacturing type.
I can't contemplate any manufacturing simply because we don't have anything to manufacture.
Well, I want to thank you again for the interview.
Well, I think that we ought to go back a little bit.
The
The community is somewhat unique.
It basically was established by the Texas New Orleans Railroad.
The original town site was Boomba, which is three miles east of the present town site.
But the Texas New Orleans Railroad came through here and bought 640 acres, a league of land,
from, really it was from the Stephen F. Austin estate.
Mr. Brown, who was related to Mr. Marriott, one of Mr. Austin's sisters, sold them the land and then they surveyed it into town lots and so forth.
And the railroad,
stopped at Milliken in 1860, which was a terminus, a railroad terminus, for a great distance of country.
Near its railhead, to the north of that railhead, was somewhere in Kansas.
And everything in between had to go one place or the other for supplies.
The Milliken Railhead, or terminus, had him taken the place of the Port of Galveston.
But the Civil War stopped it there.
And they resumed construction on the railroad after the conclusion of the Civil War.
I believe it reached Bryan in 1866.
And Bryan was a terminus for a while.
And then it moved, the railroad moved on and eventually terminated in Dallas.
but is now Dallas.
But from that time on, the town has been a very active sort of a town.
And of course, the addition of the Texas A&M College
obviously the most significant thing that really ever happened to it.
Did you say that this, in the beginning, Bryan was a railroad town?
It was a railroad terminal.
It was not a railroad town in the sense that that's understood where many railroads meet or intersect or a railhead or anything like that.
It was all of these towns were created by the railroad.
As the railroad proceeded, they actually made the town.
Many of the lots in Bryan are still owned by the Texas Town Lock Company, which was a, which is a subsidiary and part of the, let me see, what was it?
was first the Houston and Texas Central.
Then it was the Texas and New Orleans.
And then it merged with Sun City.
But the Texas Town Lock Company has been an operating identity since 1865 or 66, right here in Brown.
Do you think the railroad will ever come back?
